newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia says Ericsson telecom deal legal.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia says Ericsson telecom deal legal.

text.p: A telecommunications contract awarded to Sweden's LM Ericsson by Malaysia has been found legal by investigators probing alleged discrepancies in the deal, the national Bernama news agency reported on Wednesday.

"All procedures have clearly been observed," Bernama quoted Malaysia's Deputy Finance Minister Affifuddin Omar as saying in parliament of the contract awarded to five companies, including a joint-venture between Ericsson and Malaysia's armed forces fund board Perwira.
Malaysia launched in January this year a probe into the contract awarded by Telekom Malaysia in 1991 after a U.S. newspaper reported of alleged discrepancies.

Affifuddin said investigations showed that Perwira-Ericsson Sdn Bhd and four others -- Pernas-NEC Telecommunications Sdn Bhd, Alcatel CIT, Marubeni Corp and Sapura Holdings Sdn Bhd -- were jointly awarded the contract.
The five were awarded individual deals worth 414 million ringgit ($167 million) each to provide 800,000 lines to Telekom, Bernama said.

Affifuddin said the Malaysian Treasury and Anti-Corruption Agency began their investigations after complaints by international companies that Telekom seemed to favour Ericsson more than other companies when awarding the contract.
Affifuddin said the ACA even investigated elements of irregularities like favouritism, price escalation or contract variation in the deals. He added that there was no need to extend the probe.
